sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Asthma: (immediate-release tablets) 600 mg ORALLY 4 times daily
  • Asthma: (extended-release tablets) 1200 mg ORALLY twice daily within 1 hour after morning and evening meals

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• safety and efficacy not established in children younger than 12 years
  • Asthma: (immediate-release tablets) 12 years or older, 600 mg ORALLY 4 times daily
  • Asthma: (extended-release tablets) 12 years or older, 1200 mg ORALLY twice daily within 1 hour after morning and evening meals

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• liver disease (active) or persistent transaminase elevations of at least 3 times the upper limit of normal: use is contraindicated
  • renal impairment: no dosage adjustment necessary
  • hemodialysis: no dosage adjustment necessary

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• active liver disease
  • hypersensitivity to zileuton or any product components
  • persistent liver enzyme elevations 3 or more times the upper limit of normal

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• acute asthma attacks, including status asthmaticus; not indicated for the reversal of bronchospasm
  • alcohol intake of substantial quantities; increased risk of hepatotoxicity
  • elderly females (65 years of age or older); may be at increased risk for ALT elevations
  • hepatotoxicity may occur; monitoring recommended; discontinuation may be necessary
  • liver disease, history; increased risk of hepatotoxicity
  • neuropsychiatric events, including sleep disorders and behavior changes, have been reported in adults and adolescents; monitoring recommended; evaluate risks and benefits of treatment continuation if events occur
  • pediatric patients less than 12 years of age; use not recommended; risk of hepatotoxicity
  • report suspected adverse reactions to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Urticaria
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (1% to 5%), Indigestion (1% to 8.2%), Nausea (5% to 5.5%), Upper abdominal pain (1% to 4.8%)
  • Neurologic:Dizziness (3.3%), Headache (23% to 25.6%), Insomnia (3%)
  • Respiratory:Pain in throat (5%), Sinusitis (6.5%)
Serious
  • Hepatic:Hepatotoxicity
  • Psychiatric:Aggressive behavior, Agitation, Altered behavior, Dream disorder, Hallucinations, Suicidal thoughts

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Systemic: Zileuton is a selective inhibitor of 5-lipoxygenase, which is the enzyme that catalyzes the formation of leukotrienes from arachidonic acid. Specifically, it inhibits the formation of leukotrienes LTC 4, LTD 4, and LTE 4, which are the active constituents of slow-reacting substances of anaphylaxis, and LTB 4, a substance that attracts neutrophils and eosinophils. Leukotrienes produce numerous biological effects, including augmentation of neutrophil and eosinophil migration, neutrophil and monocyte aggregation, leukocyte adhesion, increased capillary permeability, and smooth muscle contraction. These effects contribute to inflammation, edema, mucus secretion, and bronchoconstriction in the airways of asthmatic patients.

0.title: Absorption
0.mono:
• Effect of food, immediate-release tablets: increased Cmax by 27%, no effect on AUC or Tmax
  • Effect of food, extended-release tablets: increased AUC by 34% to 43%, mean Cmax by 18%, and Cmin by 170%, Tmax prolonged from 2.1 to 4.3 h

2.title: Metabolism
2.mono:
• Hepatic; P450 CYP1A2, CYP2C9, and CYP3A4 pathways and stereoselective glucuronidation
  • Active metabolites: O-glucuronide conjugates

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • (immediate-release tablets) may be taken with or without food
  • (extended-release tablets) take within 1 hour after morning and evening meals
  • (extended-release tablets) do not chew, cut, or crush

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• improvement of pulmonary function tests, reduction of asthma symptoms, and decreased need for other asthma medications indicate efficacy
  • serum transaminases, especially ALT; baseline, during therapy starting with once monthly for 3 months, then every 2 to 3 months for the remainder of the first year, and periodically thereafter
  • neuropsychiatric events (eg, sleep disorders, behavior changes); throughout duration of therapy

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• Zyflo CR
    Oral Tablet, Extended Release: 600 MG
  • Zyflo
    Oral Tablet: 600 MG

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
ZILEUTON
OVERDOSE: limited human data. ANIMAL OVERDOSE: (Dogs): nephritis at 1000 mg/kg (12 times daily human dose). ADVERSE EFFECTS: headache, dizziness, gastrointestinal disturbances, liver function abnormalities. Risk for drug interaction via P450 CYP3A4.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
ZILEUTON
  • Support: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive.
  • Decontamination: Consider activated charcoal, gastric lavage.
  • Monitoring of patient: Evaluate concomitant drug therapies; drug monitoring as indicated. Monitor renal and liver function following significant overdose.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
ZILEUTON
No data on lethal overdoses in humans.An ingestion by an adult of 11-15 tablets (6.6-9 grams) resulted in NO sequelae.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient that this drug is not indicated for acute asthma attacks.
  • Patient should avoid activities requiring coordination until drug effects are realized, as this medicine may cause dizziness.
  • This drug may cause nausea, diarrhea, dyspepsia, sinusitis, and pharyngolaryngeal pain.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of hepatic dysfunction.
  • Instruct patient to take the extended-release tablets within 1 hour after the morning and evening meals.
  • Patient should not drink alcohol while taking this drug.
